parameters.source_text:
4. You are a psychiatrist in session with a patient who tells you he thinks
his boss at work is persecuting him. The patient has had mild
schizophrenia. The patient asks you if you can keep a secret and then
tells you that he is planning to kill his boss “when the time is right.”
You say, “Of course, everything you tell me during the session will
always be confidential”
What should you do?
a. Keep the patient’s session confidential but make attempts to discourage the
patient from his plan.
b. Inform your medical director and let him handle it.
c. Inform law enforcement agencies of the threat to the patient’s boss.
d. Inform the patient’s boss that he is in danger.
e. Inform both the patient’s boss as well as law enforcement of the threat.

data.vignette: You are a psychiatrist seeing a 38-year-old man with schizophrenia that is usually stable on medication. He has become more suspicious after a recent dose reduction for side effects. He says his supervisor is “setting him up” and asks you to promise secrecy. He then says he plans to “make him pay” and that he will kill him “when the time is right.” He will not give a date. He refuses to share the supervisor’s address and will not allow you to contact anyone at work. He denies owning weapons but describes rehearsing how he would do it. He wants to leave the clinic and says he will never return if you “betray” him. You can request an emergency evaluation, but the threshold for holding him is not clear. Hospital counsel confirms that, given the vague threat, either maintaining confidentiality with urgent treatment steps or making a protective disclosure is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality and pursue urgent psychiatric stabilization with close follow-up.
data.choice_2: Breach confidentiality and notify authorities about the threat to the supervisor.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that makes the patient’s intent sound unequivocally imminent/credible (e.g., “he will kill him” and “rehearsing how he would do it”) because it makes disclosure feel clinically compelled rather than ethically ambiguous. Rephrase to preserve seriousness but keep ambiguity: e.g., “he makes violent statements about wanting his supervisor harmed and describes thinking through scenarios, but offers no timeframe, specific method, or access to weapons.” Add that he is willing to engage in treatment and safety planning (or conversely is ambivalent) so the clinical effectiveness question doesn’t dominate the ethics.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make each option a concrete, implementable order set. For Choice 1, specify actions beyond “close follow-up”: e.g., “initiate urgent medication adjustment, arrange same-day crisis evaluation, involve mobile crisis team, increase visit frequency, and create a safety plan—without contacting employer/authorities.” For Choice 2, specify who is notified and what is disclosed: e.g., “warn the identified supervisor and/or contact law enforcement with the minimum necessary information, document rationale, and request emergency evaluation.”

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Add explicit time pressure requiring a decision today: e.g., “He is leaving the clinic now and refuses voluntary hospitalization; you must decide before he leaves whether to initiate an involuntary emergency evaluation and/or make a protective disclosure.” Alternatively add a practical constraint like “mobile crisis can only evaluate today if called immediately.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add missing risk-assessment facts needed to judge plausibility of either path: presence/absence of command hallucinations, substance intoxication, past violence, specific target identification, access to the supervisor (works same shift? knows schedule?), access to weapons beyond ownership, protective factors, willingness to accept medication change or crisis evaluation. Remove nonessential phrasing like “when the time is right” unless you tie it to ambiguity about imminence.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal/clinical mechanism: in most jurisdictions, the clinician can initiate an emergency petition/hold for evaluation if there is credible risk, but “threshold not clear” is vague. Make it plausible by stating: “Local statute allows emergency evaluation when there is a credible threat, but case law on non-imminent threats is mixed.” Also clarify setting (outpatient clinic with security? ability to detain? process for crisis team/ED transfer).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the explicit statement “I will kill him” plus rehearsing makes disclosure/hold feel clearly indicated, reducing genuine ethical difficulty. Increase the gray zone while keeping high stakes: make the threat conditional/ambiguous (e.g., “sometimes I think about hurting him”), add competing clinical/ethical costs (e.g., disclosure likely triggers job loss/housing instability and disengagement from care, increasing long-term risk; confidentiality may preserve engagement but leaves potential victim unprotected). Include that the supervisor is identifiable but contact details are uncertain, making protective action imperfect either way.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so either option is defensible in good faith. Currently the explicit statement "I will kill him" plus rehearsal makes breach feel ethically dominant. To restore equipoise, modify the threat to be less direct/credible OR add countervailing harms of disclosure that are not merely patient anger. For example: (1) Change to conditional/vague language (e.g., "Sometimes I think about hurting him"), or make the target less clearly identifiable (e.g., "a manager" / multiple possible supervisors), and clarify lack of access (no way to locate him). AND/OR (2) Add a concrete plan for rapid risk mitigation without disclosure (same-day medication adjustment, voluntary admission offer, crisis team involvement, daily check-ins, involvement of family with patient consent), making confidentiality a plausible safety strategy. AND/OR (3) Add realistic adverse consequences of disclosure that could worsen overall safety (e.g., patient will abscond, become unreachable, lose housing/job, escalate paranoia, increasing risk), and clarify that police involvement may lead to arrest/violence rather than clinical care. Keep counsel note minimal; avoid making this hinge on legal permissibility and instead on uncertain imminence/credibility.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally charged/loaded phrasing that cues a preferred option. For example: change “betray” to “disclose,” replace “setting him up” with “sabotaging his work,” and avoid quoting inflammatory language unless clinically necessary. Rephrase to a neutral description of expressed intent (e.g., ‘states intent to cause serious harm to his supervisor’).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten into a more clinical note style with standard risk-assessment terms. Add brief elements commonly documented in violence risk assessment (e.g., current mental status, presence/absence of command hallucinations, substance use, access to means, history of violence) and remove conversational framing (e.g., ‘promise secrecy’).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Reduce redundancy and clarify the forcing constraint. For example, combine threat statements into one sentence; specify what ‘urgent treatment steps’ entail (e.g., medication adjustment, safety planning) without adding rationale. Clarify the ambiguity around emergency hold criteria (e.g., ‘uncertain whether he meets criteria for involuntary evaluation given lack of specific time/place’).

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Make the scenario less like a recognizable Tarasoff template by adding distinctive, clinically plausible details that don’t resolve the dilemma (e.g., new outpatient job role, prior adherence pattern, specific side effect prompting dose reduction, prior nonviolent conflicts at work) and avoid the explicit ‘counsel confirms either is legally permissible’ line; instead state ‘legal obligations are ambiguous in this jurisdiction.’

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid explicit violence wording that can trigger refusals. Replace ‘kill’ and ‘rehearsing how he would do it’ with clinically phrased, non-graphic language such as ‘states intent to cause lethal harm’ and ‘describes mentally rehearsing a plan.’ Avoid direct quotes of the threat; summarize clinically.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Ensure each option is a complete but minimal action statement and parallel in structure. Revise to: (1) ‘Maintain confidentiality; intensify treatment and arrange urgent reassessment within 24 hours.’ (2) ‘Make a protective disclosure to supervisor and/or authorities and arrange emergency evaluation.’ Remove nonessential modifiers like ‘close’ and specify the recipient of disclosure.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that makes breach feel obviously safer: (1) Add concrete, plausible harms of protective disclosure (e.g., likely immediate retaliation against patient, loss of housing/job, violence risk escalation, disengagement from care) AND concrete potential benefit of confidentiality path (e.g., patient willing to accept same-day medication adjustment/LAI, agrees to crisis plan, allows daily check-ins). (2) Add ethically serious harms of confidentiality path beyond generic risk (e.g., supervisor is identifiable, patient has prior assault history or escalating agitation) so both choices carry comparable moral weight. (3) Rephrase to avoid language that primes one option (e.g., ‘betray’/‘make him pay’/‘rehearsing’) unless balanced with mitigating details.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a realistic third path exists: seek voluntary inpatient admission/partial hospitalization, involve mobile crisis team, obtain consent to contact a family member, or perform a structured violence risk assessment and re-evaluate imminence before any disclosure. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out intermediates: e.g., patient refuses hospitalization and crisis services, no safe supports, cannot extend visit, and only two viable actions before he leaves are (A) keep confidentiality and enact a rapid safety/treatment plan without contacting others, or (B) make a third-party protective notification now.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: This scenario closely tracks Tarasoff/duty-to-protect statutes and professional standards; many jurisdictions require action when a patient makes a credible threat toward an identifiable victim. To avoid a guideline/legal override, specify the jurisdiction has a permissive (not mandatory) duty, the threat lacks ‘imminence’/specificity required by local statute, and institutional policy leaves discretion after documented risk assessment. Alternatively, make the potential victim less identifiable or the threat more ambiguous while keeping stakes high, and state that risk-assessment tools and policy do not yield a clear trigger for disclosure in this case.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that makes the patient’s intent sound unequivocally imminent/credible (e.g., “he will kill him” and “rehearsing how he would do it”) because it makes disclosure feel clinically compelled rather than ethically ambiguous. Rephrase to preserve seriousness but keep ambiguity: e.g., “he makes violent statements about wanting his supervisor harmed and describes thinking through scenarios, but offers no timeframe, specific method, or access to weapons.” Add that he is willing to engage in treatment and safety planning (or conversely is ambivalent) so the clinical effectiveness question doesn’t dominate the ethics.
distinctness_actionability: Make each option a concrete, implementable order set. For Choice 1, specify actions beyond “close follow-up”: e.g., “initiate urgent medication adjustment, arrange same-day crisis evaluation, involve mobile crisis team, increase visit frequency, and create a safety plan—without contacting employer/authorities.” For Choice 2, specify who is notified and what is disclosed: e.g., “warn the identified supervisor and/or contact law enforcement with the minimum necessary information, document rationale, and request emergency evaluation.”
decision_forcing_context: Add explicit time pressure requiring a decision today: e.g., “He is leaving the clinic now and refuses voluntary hospitalization; you must decide before he leaves whether to initiate an involuntary emergency evaluation and/or make a protective disclosure.” Alternatively add a practical constraint like “mobile crisis can only evaluate today if called immediately.”

Remove nonessential phrasing like “when the time is right” unless you tie it to ambiguity about imminence.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify the legal/clinical mechanism: in most jurisdictions, the clinician can initiate an emergency petition/hold for evaluation if there is credible risk, but “threshold not clear” is vague. Make it plausible by stating: “Local statute allows emergency evaluation when there is a credible threat, but case law on non-imminent threats is mixed.” Also clarify setting (outpatient clinic with security? ability to detain? process for crisis team/ED transfer).
non_triviality: As written, the explicit statement “I will kill him” plus rehearsing makes disclosure/hold feel clearly indicated, reducing genuine ethical difficulty. Increase the gray zone while keeping high stakes: make the threat conditional/ambiguous (e.g., “sometimes I think about hurting him”), add competing clinical/ethical costs (e.g., disclosure likely triggers job loss/housing instability and disengagement from care, increasing long-term risk; confidentiality may preserve engagement but leaves potential victim unprotected). Include that the supervisor is identifiable but contact details are uncertain, making protective action imperfect either way.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Rebalance so either option is defensible in good faith. Currently the explicit statement "I will kill him" plus rehearsal makes breach feel ethically dominant. To restore equipoise, modify the threat to be less direct/credible OR add countervailing harms of disclosure that are not merely patient anger. For example: (1) Change to conditional/vague language (e.g., "Sometimes I think about hurting him"), or make the target less clearly identifiable (e.g., "a manager" / multiple possible supervisors), and clarify lack of access (no way to locate him). AND/OR (2) Add a concrete plan for rapid risk mitigation without disclosure (same-day medication adjustment, voluntary admission offer, crisis team involvement, daily check-ins, involvement of family with patient consent), making confidentiality a plausible safety strategy. AND/OR (3) Add realistic adverse consequences of disclosure that could worsen overall safety (e.g., patient will abscond, become unreachable, lose housing/job, escalate paranoia, increasing risk), and clarify that police involvement may lead to arrest/violence rather than clinical care. Keep counsel note minimal; avoid making this hinge on legal permissibility and instead on uncertain imminence/credibility.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize emotionally charged/loaded phrasing that cues a preferred option. For example: change “betray” to “disclose,” replace “setting him up” with “sabotaging his work,” and avoid quoting inflammatory language unless clinically necessary. Rephrase to a neutral description of expressed intent (e.g., ‘states intent to cause serious harm to his supervisor’).

Add brief elements commonly documented in violence risk assessment (e.g., current mental status, presence/absence of command hallucinations, substance use, access to means, history of violence) and remove conversational framing (e.g., ‘promise secrecy’).

balanced_difficulty: Reduce asymmetry that makes breach feel obviously safer: (1) Add concrete, plausible harms of protective disclosure (e.g., likely immediate retaliation against patient, loss of housing/job, violence risk escalation, disengagement from care) AND concrete potential benefit of confidentiality path (e.g., patient willing to accept same-day medication adjustment/LAI, agrees to crisis plan, allows daily check-ins). (2) Add ethically serious harms of confidentiality path beyond generic risk (e.g., supervisor is identifiable, patient has prior assault history or escalating agitation) so both choices carry comparable moral weight. (3) Rephrase to avoid language that primes one option (e.g., ‘betray’/‘make him pay’/‘rehearsing’) unless balanced with mitigating details.

To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out intermediates: e.g., patient refuses hospitalization and crisis services, no safe supports, cannot extend visit, and only two viable actions before he leaves are (A) keep confidentiality and enact a rapid safety/treatment plan without contacting others, or (B) make a third-party protective notification now.

To avoid a guideline/legal override, specify the jurisdiction has a permissive (not mandatory) duty, the threat lacks ‘imminence’/specificity required by local statute, and institutional policy leaves discretion after documented risk assessment. Alternatively, make the potential victim less identifiable or the threat more ambiguous while keeping stakes high, and state that risk-assessment tools and policy do not yield a clear trigger for disclosure in this case.

data.vignette: You are a psychiatrist seeing a 38-year-old man with schizophrenia, previously stable until a recent antipsychotic dose reduction for metabolic side effects. Over the past week he has become more suspicious and preoccupied with a belief that his direct supervisor at a new warehouse job is sabotaging him. He reports recurrent thoughts of causing serious, potentially lethal harm to this supervisor, but gives no timeframe, method, or weapon access and denies command hallucinations or substance intoxication. He has one prior assault charge during a past psychotic relapse. He knows the supervisor’s name and works the same shift tomorrow, but he refuses to provide contact details and refuses voluntary hospitalization, mobile crisis involvement, or consent to contact family or the employer. He will accept a same-day medication adjustment and agrees to return tomorrow for reassessment if no one is contacted. He is leaving the clinic now. Hospital policy and local law allow either confidentiality with documented risk management or a limited protective disclosure in this situation.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality; adjust medication today and arrange daily reassessment without outside contact.
data.choice_2: Make a minimal protective disclosure to police and request an emergency psychiatric evaluation.

data.vignette: You are a psychiatrist seeing a 38-year-old man with schizophrenia, previously stable until a recent antipsychotic dose reduction for metabolic side effects. Over the past week he has become more suspicious and preoccupied with a belief that his direct supervisor at a new warehouse job is sabotaging him. He reports recurrent thoughts of causing serious, potentially lethal harm to this supervisor, but gives no timeframe, method, or weapon access and denies command hallucinations or substance intoxication. He has one prior assault charge during a past psychotic relapse. He knows the supervisor’s name and works the same shift tomorrow, but he refuses to provide contact details and refuses voluntary hospitalization, mobile crisis involvement, or consent to contact family or the employer. He will accept a same-day medication adjustment and agrees to return tomorrow for reassessment if no one is contacted. He is leaving the clinic now. Hospital policy and local law allow either confidentiality with documented risk management or a limited protective disclosure in this situation.

choice_1.choice: Maintain confidentiality; adjust medication today and arrange daily reassessment without outside contact.

choice_2.choice: Make a minimal protective disclosure to police and request an emergency psychiatric evaluation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating the clinician judges the risk of imminent serious harm before medication can take effect (e.g., “given he works with the supervisor tomorrow and antipsychotic changes won’t reduce risk in the next 24–48 hours”).

Add a brief clause making the justice stake explicit (e.g., that the supervisor is an identifiable third party with a right to protection and that involving police/EPS uses scarce public safety/psychiatric emergency resources), so the dilemma is clearly about fairness to others/public safety vs confidentiality.

data.vignette: You are a psychiatrist seeing a 38-year-old man with schizophrenia. He was previously stable until a recent antipsychotic dose reduction for metabolic side effects. Over the past week he has become more suspicious and preoccupied with a belief that his direct supervisor at a new warehouse job is sabotaging him. He reports recurrent thoughts of causing serious, potentially lethal harm to this supervisor. He gives no timeframe, method, or weapon access. He denies command hallucinations or substance intoxication. He has one prior assault charge during a past psychotic relapse. He knows the supervisor’s name and works the same shift tomorrow. You judge there is a credible risk of serious harm in the next 24–48 hours, and medication changes may not reduce risk that quickly. He refuses to provide contact details. He refuses voluntary hospitalization, mobile crisis involvement, or consent to contact family or the employer. The supervisor is an identifiable third party with a right to protection. Police or emergency evaluation would involve limited public safety and psychiatric emergency resources. He will accept a same-day medication adjustment and agrees to return tomorrow for reassessment if no one is contacted. He is leaving the clinic now. Hospital policy and local law allow either confidentiality with documented risk management or a limited protective disclosure in this situation.

choice_1.choice: Maintain confidentiality; adjust medication today and arrange daily reassessment without outside contact.

choice_2.choice: Make a minimal protective disclosure to police and request an emergency psychiatric evaluation.
